elements.content: Two new metal coordination polymers with interesting supramolecular architectures, [Mn(H2O)4(L)] n (ClO4)2 n ·2nL1 (1) and [Ag(L1)(NO3)] n (2) [L1 = 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene], have been synthesized and characterized structurally. Complex 1 exhibits a novel supramolecular layer architecture sustained by the concurrence of coordination bonds, hydrogen bonds, and π−π stacking interactions:  the Mn(II) ions are coordinated by water molecules and the bridging μ2-L1 ligands to yield one-dimensional (1D) zigzag [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n coordination chains; the free L1 ligands are hydrogen bonded to half of the coordinated water molecules and form π−π stacking triads with the bridging ligands, generating three-strand supramolecular ribbons; and the perchlorate ions form hydrogen bonds with the remaining coordinated water molecules, interlinking the ribbons into an unusual triple-decked supramolecular layer. In complex 2, each Ag(I) ion is tetracoordinated by two μ2-L1 and two μ2-nitrate ligands. The μ2-L1 ligands connect the metal ions into infinite 1D helix-like AgL1 chains, and the μ2-nitrate ions interlink the chains into undulate coordination layers. C−H···O weak hydrogen bonds exist between neighboring layers in 2.
elements.clean_text: Two new metal coordination polymers with interesting supramolecular architectures, [Mn(H2O)4(L)] n (ClO4)2  n ⋅2nL1 (1) and [Ag(L1)(NO3)] n  (2) [L1 = 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene], have been synthesized and characterized structurally. Complex 1 exhibits a novel supramolecular layer architecture sustained by the concurrence of coordination bonds, hydrogen bonds, and π-π stacking interactions: the Mn(II) ions are coordinated by water molecules and the bridging μ2-L1 ligands to yield one-dimensional (1D) zigzag [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n  coordination chains; the free L1 ligands are hydrogen bonded to half of the coordinated water molecules and form π-π stacking triads with the bridging ligands, generating three-strand supramolecular ribbons; and the perchlorate ions form hydrogen bonds with the remaining coordinated water molecules, interlinking the ribbons into an unusual triple-decked supramolecular layer. In complex 2, each Ag(I) ion is tetracoordinated by two μ2-L1 and two μ2-nitrate ligands. The μ2-L1 ligands connect the metal ions into infinite 1D helix-like AgL1 chains, and the μ2-nitrate ions interlink the chains into undulate coordination layers. C-H⋅⋅⋅O weak hydrogen bonds exist between neighboring layers in 2.

elements.content: Two coordination polymers with novel supramolecular architectures have been generated from a ditopic Schiff-base ligand with specific geometry:  in the Mn(II) complex, coordination, hydrogen bonding, and π−π stacking interactions operate concurrently to sustain a 2D triple-decked supramolecular architecture based on 1D coordination backbones, while in the Ag(I) complex, 1D helix-like coordination chains are cross-linked by nitrate ions into undulate 2D layers.
elements.clean_text: Two coordination polymers with novel supramolecular architectures have been generated from a ditopic Schiff-base ligand with specific geometry: in the Mn(II) complex, coordination, hydrogen bonding, and π-π stacking interactions operate concurrently to sustain a 2D triple-decked supramolecular architecture based on 1D coordination backbones, while in the Ag(I) complex, 1D helix-like coordination chains are cross-linked by nitrate ions into undulate 2D layers.

elements.content: In the past decade, the design, construction, and elucidation of multidimensional supramolecular solid-state architectures have attracted considerable attention in the context of crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry. The drives arise not only from the pragmatic perspective to obtain new technologically relevant materials, but also from the scientists' natural interest to reveal the intriguing beauty and diversity of the architectures that can be assembled and to understand the laws of physics determining the assembly processes. The useful tools in crystal engineering have been weak noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking for organic architectures, and metal−ligand coordination bonds for inorganic−organic hybrid coordination networks, and at the meeting point, the interplay of coordination bonds with noncovalent interactions has also been employed to construct new inorganic−organic architectures. In the last case, the noncovalent interactions may serve as the forces interlinking discrete or low-dimensional coordination motifs (and other components) into higher-dimensional architectures or as additional forces sustaining the coordination networks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, the design, construction, and elucidation of multidimensional supramolecular solid-state architectures have attracted considerable attention in the context of crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry. The drives arise not only from the pragmatic perspective to obtain new technologically relevant materials, but also from the scientists' natural interest to reveal the intriguing beauty and diversity of the architectures that can be assembled and to understand the laws of physics determining the assembly processes. The useful tools in crystal engineering have been weak noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking for organic architectures, and metal-ligand coordination bonds for inorganic-organic hybrid coordination networks, and at the meeting point, the interplay of coordination bonds with noncovalent interactions has also been employed to construct new inorganic-organic architectures. In the last case, the noncovalent interactions may serve as the forces interlinking discrete or low-dimensional coordination motifs (and other components) into higher-dimensional architectures or as additional forces sustaining the coordination networks.

elements.content: The most widely used organic bridging ligands for coordination polymers have been those containing two or more pyridyl (especially 4-pyridyl) groups separated by various spacers, rigid or flexible, such as 4,4-bipyridine and 1,2-bis(4‘-pyridyl)ethane/ethene/ethyne, from which a rich variety of one- (1D), two- (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) metal−organic polymeric architectures have been constructed. These have been summarized by several excellent reviews, and a recent review by Roesky focused on bis(4-pyridyl)-derived inorganic−organic networks with high-dimensional supramolecular architectures sustained by the interplay of coordination, hydrogen bonding, and π−π stacking interactions. Recently, zur Loye and co-workers reported two ditopic Schiff-base ligands containing terminal 3-pyridyl groups (Scheme :  L1 = 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene; L2 = 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene). The specific geometric features of these ligands, mainly the off-axis coordination orientation of the 3-pyridyl rings and the flexibility of the zigzag -(R)CN−NC(R)- central moiety, have allowed the authors to obtain new Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with interesting structures difficult to achieve by other bis(pyridyl) derivatives:8 L1 forms 1D double-bridged [M(NO3)2(L1)2] n coordination chains interlinked by C−H···O hydrogen bonds into 2D layers, while L2 forms unusual 2D or 3D coordination networks dependent upon solvent systems. The studies on the ligands have thus far been limited to Co(II) and Cd(II) systems. Considering the flexibility and other interesting features of such ligands, we conducted the investigation with other metal ions, in hopes of obtaining new metal−organic architectures. Here we report the synthesis and crystal structure of two new complexes of L1, [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n (ClO4)2 n ·2nL1 (1) and [Ag(L1)(NO3)] n (2). It turned out that the L1 ligand in these complexes adopts different conformations from that in the known Co(II) and Cd(II) complexes, resulting in new and interesting supramolecular structures. Complex 1 exhibits an unusual triple-decked supramolecular layer architecture in which 1D [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n coordination chains interact with free L1 ligands and perchlorate ions via hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking, while complex 2 contains undulate coordination layers in which 1D helix-like AgL1 chains are cross-linked by nitrate ions.
elements.clean_text: The most widely used organic bridging ligands for coordination polymers have been those containing two or more pyridyl (especially 4-pyridyl) groups separated by various spacers, rigid or flexible, such as 4,4-bipyridine and 1,2-bis(4‘-pyridyl)ethane/ethene/ethyne, from which a rich variety of one- (1D), two- (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic polymeric architectures have been constructed. These have been summarized by several excellent reviews, and a recent review by Roesky focused on bis(4-pyridyl)-derived inorganic-organic networks with high-dimensional supramolecular architectures sustained by the interplay of coordination, hydrogen bonding, and π-π stacking interactions. Recently, zur Loye and co-workers reported two ditopic Schiff-base ligands containing terminal 3-pyridyl groups (Scheme : L1 = 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene; L2 = 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene). The specific geometric features of these ligands, mainly the off-axis coordination orientation of the 3-pyridyl rings and the flexibility of the zigzag -(R)CN-NC(R)- central moiety, have allowed the authors to obtain new Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with interesting structures difficult to achieve by other bis(pyridyl) derivatives:8 L1 forms 1D double-bridged [M(NO3)2(L1)2] n  coordination chains interlinked by C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds into 2D layers, while L2 forms unusual 2D or 3D coordination networks dependent upon solvent systems. The studies on the ligands have thus far been limited to Co(II) and Cd(II) systems. Considering the flexibility and other interesting features of such ligands, we conducted the investigation with other metal ions, in hopes of obtaining new metal-organic architectures. Here we report the synthesis and crystal structure of two new complexes of L1, [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n (ClO4)2  n ⋅2nL1 (1) and [Ag(L1)(NO3)] n  (2). It turned  out that the L1 ligand in these complexes adopts different conformations from that in the known Co(II) and Cd(II) complexes, resulting in new and interesting supramolecular structures. Complex 1 exhibits an unusual triple-decked supramolecular layer architecture in which 1D [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n  coordination chains interact with free L1 ligands and perchlorate ions via hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking, while complex 2 contains undulate coordination layers in which 1D helix-like AgL1 chains are cross-linked by nitrate ions.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg049659xh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2004-09659x_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Materials and Synthesis. All the starting chemicals were of A. R. grade and used as received. The L1 ligand was prepared according to the literature method.

CAUTION! Although not encountered in our experiments, metal perchlorates are potentially explosive. They should be handled with care.

[Mn(H 2 O) 4 (L 1 )] n (ClO 4 ) 2 n · 2 n L 1 (1). A methanol solution (4 mL) of Mn(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.20 mmol) was mixed under stirring with the solution (6 mL) of the L1 ligand (0.40 mmol) in the same solvent. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for three weeks, affording yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with methanol and ether successively, and dried in air. Yield:  74% (based on the ligand). When the starting Mn/L1 molar ratio was changed to 1:3, which corresponds to the stoichiometry of 1, the same compound was obtained. Anal. Calcd for C42H50Cl2MnN12O12:  C 48.47, H 4.84, N 16.15; Found:  C 48.40, H 4.68, N 16.55%. Main IR (cm-1):  3409m, 1614s, 1421s, 1371s, 1306m, 1200m, 1121vs, 1034s, 931m, 825m, 707m.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Synthesis. All the starting chemicals were of A. R. grade and used as received. The L1 ligand was prepared according to the literature method. 

 CAUTION! Although not encountered in our experiments, metal perchlorates are potentially explosive. They should be handled with care. 

 [Mn(H  2  O)  4  (L  1   )]   n   (ClO  4  )  2    n   ⋅ 2  n  L  1    (1). A methanol solution (4 mL) of Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.20 mmol) was mixed under stirring with the solution (6 mL) of the L1 ligand (0.40 mmol) in the same solvent. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for three weeks, affording yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with methanol and ether successively, and dried in air. Yield: 74% (based on the ligand). When the starting Mn/L1 molar ratio was changed to 1:3, which corresponds to the stoichiometry of 1, the same compound was obtained. Anal. Calcd for C42H50Cl2MnN12O12: C 48.47, H 4.84, N 16.15; Found: C 48.40, H 4.68, N 16.55%. Main IR (cm-1): 3409m, 1614s, 1421s, 1371s, 1306m, 1200m, 1121vs, 1034s, 931m, 825m, 707m.

elements.content: [Ag(L 1 )(NO 3 )] n (2). This compound was initially prepared as a polycrystalline yellow product, which precipitated immediately upon mixing the methanol solutions of L1 and AgNO3 (1:1 mole ratio), Yield:  89%. The reaction in acetonitrile gave similar results. Crystals of the compound were obtained by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube:  A dichloromethane solution (4 mL) of L1 (0.2 mmol) and an acetonitrile solution (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol) were respectively added into the two sides of the H-shaped tube, and then about 5 mL of acetonitrile was carefully added so that the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded yellow crystals of 2 within 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H14AgN5O3:  C 41.20, H 3.46, N 17.16; Found:  C 41.46, H 3.34, N 17.33%. Main IR (cm-1):  1612s, 1422m, 1353s, 1318vs, 1196m, 823m, 701m.
elements.clean_text: [Ag(L  1   )(NO  3  )]   n    (2). This compound was initially prepared as a polycrystalline yellow product, which precipitated immediately upon mixing the methanol solutions of L1 and AgNO3 (1:1 mole ratio), Yield: 89%. The reaction in acetonitrile gave similar results. Crystals of the compound were obtained by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube: A dichloromethane solution (4 mL) of L1 (0.2 mmol) and an acetonitrile solution (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol) were respectively added into the two sides of the H-shaped tube, and then about 5 mL of acetonitrile was carefully added so that the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded yellow crystals of 2 within 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H14AgN5O3: C 41.20, H 3.46, N 17.16; Found: C 41.46, H 3.34, N 17.33%. Main IR (cm-1): 1612s, 1422m, 1353s, 1318vs, 1196m, 823m, 701m.

elements.content: Physical Measurements. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer equipped with a Nic-Plan microscope.
elements.clean_text: Physical Measurements. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer equipped with a Nic-Plan microscope.

elements.content: Crystallographic Studies. Diffraction intensity data of the single crystals were collected at 293 K on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the Sortav program. All structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were placed geometrically at calculated positions and refined using the riding model, and the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from the difference maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic Studies. Diffraction intensity data of the single crystals were collected at 293 K on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the Sortav program. All structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were placed geometrically at calculated positions and refined using the riding model, and the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from the difference maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table .

The Mn(II) Complex (1). This complex was prepared by reacting manganese perchlorate and the L1 ligand in methanol. The IR spectrum of the complex exhibits a medium broad band centered at ca. 3409 cm-1, due to the ν(O−H) absorptions of water molecules. The strong absorption at 1614 cm-1 is attributable to the ν(CN) vibration of the ligand, and the very strong absorptions at 1121 and 1034 cm-1 indicate the presence of the perchlorate ion.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 The Mn(II) Complex (1). This complex was prepared by reacting manganese perchlorate and the L1 ligand in methanol. The IR spectrum of the complex exhibits a medium broad band centered at ca. 3409 cm-1, due to the ν(O-H) absorptions of water molecules. The strong absorption at 1614 cm-1 is attributable to the ν(CN) vibration of the ligand, and the very strong absorptions at 1121 and 1034 cm-1 indicate the presence of the perchlorate ion.

elements.content: X-ray analyses revealed that the structure of 1 consists of infinite 1D cationic coordination chains [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n 2 n +, noncoordinated L1 ligands and perchlorate anions, and that all the above components are involved in an interesting extensive hydrogen-bonding system. A perspective view of the building blocks with the atom-labeling scheme is given in Figure , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Each manganese(II) ion resides at an inversion center and assumes a trans-octahedral coordination geometry with axial elongation, with four aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane (av. Mn−O, 2.15 Å) and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from different (crystallographically equivalent) L1 ligands at the axial positions (Mn−N, 2.31 Å). The coordinated L1 ligands, also located at inversion centers, assume a transoid but nonplanar (although rather flat) conformation:  the two pyridyl rings in each ligand are strictly antiparallel to each other, and both are rotated around the respective py−C bonds by 20.5° with respect to the central -(Me)CN−NC(Me)- portion, which is almost strictly planar (including the methyl carbons). The ligands with such a conformation serve as bridges to link the Mn(II) ions into a -Mn−L1−Mn−L1- zigzag chain along the (101) direction, the Mn···Mn distance along the chain being 14.66 Å. With all metal ions in a chain being strictly collinear, the zigzag shape arises from the tilted disposition of the L1 ligand with respect to the M···M line, and the tilted disposition is dictated by the specific coordination orientation of the terminal 3-pyridyl rings. The cocrystallized uncoordinated L1 ligand adopts a different transoid conformation:  the two pyridyl rings are rotated around the respective py−C bonds by 29.9 and 5.5°, respectively, with respect to the planar -(Me)CN−NC(Me)- portion, leading to a dihedral angle of ca. 25.9° between the two pyridyl rings.
elements.clean_text: X-ray analyses revealed that the structure of 1 consists of infinite 1D cationic coordination chains [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n  2  n  +, noncoordinated L1 ligands and perchlorate anions, and that all the above components are involved in an interesting extensive hydrogen-bonding system. A perspective view of the building blocks with the atom-labeling scheme is given in Figure , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Each manganese(II) ion resides at an inversion center and assumes a trans-octahedral coordination geometry with axial elongation, with four aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial plane (av. Mn-O, 2.15 Å) and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from different (crystallographically equivalent) L1 ligands at the axial positions (Mn-N, 2.31 Å). The coordinated L1 ligands, also located at inversion centers, assume a transoid but nonplanar (although rather flat) conformation: the two pyridyl rings in each ligand are strictly antiparallel to each other, and both are rotated around the respective py-C bonds by 20.5° with respect to the central -(Me)CN-NC(Me)- portion, which is almost strictly planar (including the methyl carbons). The ligands with such a conformation serve as bridges to link the Mn(II) ions into a -Mn-L1-Mn-L1- zigzag chain along the (101) direction, the Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance along the chain being 14.66 Å. With all metal ions in a chain being strictly collinear, the zigzag shape arises from the tilted disposition of the L1 ligand with respect to the M⋅⋅⋅M line, and the tilted disposition is dictated by the specific coordination orientation of the terminal 3-pyridyl rings. The  cocrystallized uncoordinated L1 ligand adopts a different transoid conformation: the two pyridyl rings are rotated around the respective py-C bonds by 29.9 and 5.5°, respectively, with respect to the planar -(Me)CN-NC(Me)- portion, leading to a dihedral angle of ca. 25.9° between the two pyridyl rings.

elements.content: A perspective view of the building blocks of1 with the atom-labeling scheme. The thermal ellipsoids were drawn at 30% possibility.
elements.clean_text: 1  A perspective view of the building blocks of1 with the atom-labeling scheme. The thermal ellipsoids were drawn at 30% possibility.

elements.content: The most intriguing feature of 1 is the supramolecular structure generated via second-sphere coordination, which is achieved by the coordinated aqua ligands forming hydrogen bonds with the uncoordinated L1 ligands and the perchlorate ions. The hydrogen-bonding parameters are collected in Table . It is interesting to note that all the aqua hydrogen atoms have been involved in second-sphere hydrogen bonding, and thus a total of eight hydrogen bonds are formed for each Mn(II) chromophore. As shown in Figure , two equivalent trans aqua molecules from each Mn(II) ion are hydrogen bonded to four equivalent uncoordinated L1 molecules (Table , O1-H12···N6 and O1−H11···N3C), and each of the L1 molecules forms hydrogen bonds with two aqua molecules from neighboring metal ions of the same chain. Thus, the uncoordinated L1 ligands serve as bridges between the aqua molecules, generating infinite hydrogen-bonded ···L1···W···L1···W··· (W = water) chains that run parallel to the coordination-bonded chain. Each coordination-bonded chain is escorted by two hydrogen-bonded chains on opposite sides, affording an interesting 1D three-strand Mn(H2O)2(L1)3 ribbon (Figure , left), in which the linear O−Mn−O linkages serve as the crossbars separating and supporting the three parallel strands. Furthermore, the three L1 ligands between each two neighboring Mn(II) ions are aligned in a overlapping fashion and form a π−π stacking array. As shown in Figure (right), each pyridyl ring (e.g., the N1 ring in Figure ) of the coordinated ligand overlaps, in an offset way, with two pyridyl rings (the N6 and N3A rings in Figure ) from the hydrogen-bonded ligands. The dihedral angles between the interacting rings are 14.5° between the N1 and N6 rings and 11.4° between the N1 and N3A rings, and the interplanar and centroid−centroid distances are, respectively, 3.71 and 3.86 Å between the N1 and N6 rings, and 3.61 and 3.81 Å between the N1 and N3A rings. These parameters lie within the usual ranges for aromatic azacyclic groups in metal complexes. The formation of the π−π stacking triads should provide additional stabilizing energy for the three-strand ribbons.
elements.clean_text: The most intriguing feature of 1 is the supramolecular structure generated via second-sphere coordination, which is achieved by the coordinated aqua ligands forming hydrogen bonds with the uncoordinated L1 ligands and the perchlorate ions. The hydrogen-bonding parameters are collected in Table . It is interesting to note that all the aqua hydrogen atoms have been involved in second-sphere hydrogen bonding, and thus a total of eight hydrogen bonds are formed for each Mn(II) chromophore. As shown in Figure , two equivalent trans aqua molecules from each Mn(II) ion are hydrogen bonded to four equivalent uncoordinated L1 molecules (Table , O1-H12⋅⋅⋅N6 and O1-H11⋅⋅⋅N3C), and each of the L1 molecules forms hydrogen bonds with two aqua molecules from neighboring metal ions of the same chain. Thus, the uncoordinated L1 ligands serve as bridges between the aqua molecules, generating infinite hydrogen-bonded ⋅⋅⋅L1⋅⋅⋅W⋅⋅⋅L1⋅⋅⋅W⋅⋅⋅ (W = water) chains that run parallel to the coordination-bonded chain. Each coordination-bonded chain is escorted by two hydrogen-bonded chains on opposite sides, affording an interesting 1D three-strand Mn(H2O)2(L1)3 ribbon (Figure , left), in which the linear O-Mn-O linkages serve as the crossbars separating and supporting the three parallel strands. Furthermore, the three L1 ligands between each two neighboring Mn(II) ions are aligned in a overlapping fashion and form a π-π stacking array. As shown in Figure  (right), each pyridyl ring (e.g., the N1 ring in Figure ) of the coordinated ligand overlaps, in an offset way, with two pyridyl rings (the N6 and N3A rings in Figure ) from the hydrogen-bonded ligands. The dihedral angles between the interacting rings are 14.5° between the N1 and N6 rings and 11.4° between the N1 and N3A rings, and the interplanar and centroid-centroid distances are, respectively, 3.71 and 3.86 Å between the N1 and N6 rings, and 3.61 and 3.81 Å between the N1 and N3A rings. These parameters lie within the usual ranges for aromatic azacyclic groups in metal complexes. The formation of the π-π stacking triads should provide additional stabilizing energy for the three-strand ribbons.

elements.content: The 1D three-strand ribbon supported by first- and second-sphere coordination in1 (left) and the view highlighting the triple π−π stacking arrays in the ribbon (right).
elements.clean_text: 2  The 1D three-strand ribbon supported by first- and second-sphere coordination in1 (left) and the view highlighting the triple π-π stacking arrays in the ribbon (right).

elements.content:
Selected Bond Lengths (Å) and Angles (°) for Complex1 a

Mn1−O1 2.1426(16) Mn1−N1 2.3079(16) Mn1−O2 2.1594(17) N2−N2A 1.403(4) O1B−Mn1−O1 180.0 O2−Mn1−N1 91.54(7) O1−Mn1−O2 91.25(7) O1−Mn1−N1B 89.66(6) O1−Mn1−O2B 88.75(7) O2−Mn1−N1B 88.46(7) O2−Mn1−O2B 180.0 N1−Mn1−N1B 180.0 O1−Mn1−N1 90.34(6)

a  Symmetry codes:  A −x + 1, −y, −z + 1; B −x, −y, −z.

Relevant Distances (Å) and Angles (°) for the Hydrogen Bonds in Complex1 a

D−H···A d(D−H) d(H···A) d(D···A) <(DHA) O1−H12···N6 0.897(16) 1.891(17) 2.788(2) 178(3) O1−H11···N3C 0.943(17) 1.848(16) 2.781(3) 169(3) O2−H22···O5 0.928(18) 2.01(2) 2.887(4) 157(4) O2−H21···O6D 0.931(17) 1.860(19) 2.784(3) 171(3)

a  Symmetry codes:  C x − 1, y, z − 1; D −x + 1, −y, −z.

The three-strand ribbons are further linked into layers via the second-sphere coordination of perchlorate ions to the remaining two trans aqua molecules around each Mn(II) ion. Each of the aqua molecules forms hydrogen bonds with two perchlorate ions (Table , O2−H22···O5 and O2−H21···O6D), and each perchlorate ion forms hydrogen bonds with two aqua molecules from neighboring chains. Consequently, two perchlorate ions and two aqua molecules complete a 12-membered hydrogen-bonded ring [graph set R4 4(12), Figure ], and neighboring rings are joined by the O−Mn−O coordination linkages to produce a supramolecular Mn(H2O)2(ClO4)2 chain along the a direction (Mn···Mn, 8.92 Å). The chains intersect the three-strand ribbons at Mn(II) ions to generate an interesting and very thick triple-decked layer extending along the (010) plane (Figure ). The layer has a (4, 4) net topology with the O−Mn−O as the nodes and the triple L1 bridges and double perchlorate bridges as the connectors. The layers stacked down the b direction without evident interlayer hydrogen bonding or π−π interactions (Figure , bottom).
elements.clean_text: The three-strand ribbons are further linked into layers via the second-sphere coordination of perchlorate ions to the remaining two trans aqua molecules around each Mn(II) ion. Each of the aqua molecules forms hydrogen bonds with two perchlorate ions (Table , O2-H22⋅⋅⋅O5 and O2-H21⋅⋅⋅O6D), and each perchlorate ion forms hydrogen bonds with two aqua molecules from neighboring chains. Consequently, two perchlorate ions and two aqua molecules complete a 12-membered hydrogen-bonded ring [graph set R4 4(12), Figure ], and neighboring rings are joined by the O-Mn-O coordination linkages to produce a supramolecular Mn(H2O)2(ClO4)2 chain along the a direction (Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn, 8.92 Å). The chains intersect the three-strand ribbons at Mn(II) ions to generate an interesting and very thick triple-decked layer extending along the (010) plane (Figure ). The layer has a (4, 4) net topology with the O-Mn-O as the nodes and the triple L1 bridges and double perchlorate bridges as the connectors. The layers stacked down the b direction without evident interlayer hydrogen bonding or π-π interactions (Figure , bottom).

elements.content: The Ag(I) Complex (2). This complex can be prepared by directly mixing silver nitrate and L1 in solution, or by slow diffusion in the H-shaped tube. The complex exhibits a strong IR absorption at 1612 cm-1, assignable to the ν(CN) vibration of the ligand. The two strong bands at 1353 and 1318 cm-1 should be due to the nitrate ion.
elements.clean_text: The Ag(I) Complex (2). This complex can be prepared by directly mixing silver nitrate and L1 in solution, or by slow diffusion in the H-shaped tube. The complex exhibits a strong IR absorption at 1612 cm-1, assignable to the ν(CN) vibration of the ligand. The two strong bands at 1353 and 1318 cm-1 should be due to the nitrate ion.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analyses revealed that the structure of complex 2 consists of infinite 2D coordination layers in which 1D cationic Ag−L1 chains are cross-linked by weakly coordinated nitrate ions. A perspective view of the coordination unit with the atom-labeling scheme is given in Figure . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Each silver(I) ion, residing on a 2-fold axis, is ligated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two equivalent L1 ligands and two oxygen atoms from two equivalent nitrate ions, with a highly distorted tetrahedral geometry:  the Ag−O distances are much longer than the Ag−N ones (2.68 vs 2.18 Å), and the tetrahedron is significantly compressed, with the N1−Ag1−N1A angle (163.7°) deviating significantly from 109.4°. These parameters reflect the preference of Ag(I) to linear coordination. Each L1 ligand is located at an inversion center and assumes a transoid and nearly planar conformation:  the two pyridyl rings are rotated around the respective py−C bonds by only 4° with respect to the central −(Me)CN−NC(Me)- planar portion. Such ligands serve as zigzag bridges to link the Ag(I) ions into an infinite -Ag−L1−Ag−L1- helix-like chain along the (1̄02) direction (Figure ). The helix-like shape of the chain arises from several concurrent factors:  the specific coordination orientations of the 3-pyridyl rings, the transoid conformation of the L1 ligand, and the crossed and noncoplanar arrangement of the neighboring ligands bonded to the same Ag(I) ion. The N(py)···N(py) lines of two neighboring ligands cross each other at an angle of 64.5°, and the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two ligands is 66.0°. The Ag···Ag distance (12.13 Å) spanned by the ligand is much shorter than the Mn···Mn distance in 1, although the Ag(I) ion is larger than the Mn(II) ion. This may be attributed to the different conformation of the pyridylimine moieties in the two complexes:  in 1, each pyridylimine moiety is transoid with the pyridyl and imine nitrogen atoms in the opposite sides of the Py−C bond, while in 2, the moiety is cisoid with the two nitrogen atoms in the same side of the Py−C bond.

Each silver(I) ion, residing on a 2-fold axis, is ligated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two equivalent L1 ligands and two oxygen atoms from two equivalent nitrate ions, with a highly distorted tetrahedral geometry: the Ag-O distances are much longer than the Ag-N ones (2.68 vs 2.18 Å), and the tetrahedron is significantly compressed, with the N1-Ag1-N1A angle (163.7°) deviating significantly from 109.4°. These parameters reflect the preference of Ag(I) to linear coordination. Each L1 ligand is located at an inversion center and assumes a transoid and nearly planar conformation: the two pyridyl rings are rotated around the respective py-C bonds by only 4° with respect to the central -(Me)CN-NC(Me)- planar portion. Such ligands serve as zigzag bridges to link the Ag(I) ions into an infinite -Ag-L1-Ag-L1- helix-like chain along the (1̄02) direction (Figure ). The helix-like shape of the chain arises from several concurrent factors: the specific coordination orientations of the 3-pyridyl rings, the transoid conformation of the L1 ligand, and the crossed and noncoplanar arrangement of the neighboring ligands bonded to the same Ag(I) ion. The N(py)⋅⋅⋅N(py) lines of two neighboring ligands cross each other at an angle of 64.5°, and the dihedral angle between the mean planes of the two ligands is 66.0°. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance (12.13 Å) spanned by the ligand is much shorter than the Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance in 1, although the Ag(I) ion is larger than the Mn(II) ion. This  may be attributed to the different conformation of the pyridylimine moieties in the two complexes: in 1, each pyridylimine moiety is transoid with the pyridyl and imine nitrogen atoms in the opposite sides of the Py-C bond, while in 2, the moiety is cisoid with the two nitrogen atoms in the same side of the Py-C bond.

elements.content:
Selected Bond Lengths (Å) and Angles (°) for Complex2 a

Ag1−N1 2.1831(19) N3−O2 1.230(4) Ag1−O1 2.685(2) N3−O1 1.243(2) N2−N2B 1.392(4) N3−O1C 1.244(2) N1−Ag1−N1A 163.75(11) N1A−Ag1−O1 97.05(7) N1−Ag1−O1 93.02(7) O1A−Ag1−O1 103.34(9)

a  Symmetry codes:  A −x + 1, y, −z + 1/2; B −x + 2, −y, −z; C −x, y, −z + 1/2.

Each nitrate ion, with the central nitrogen and the uncoordinated oxygen (N3 and O2) residing on a 2-fold axis, uses its two equivalent oxygen atoms to bind two Ag(I) ions from different -Ag−L1- chains. Consequently, a zigzag AgNO3 chain along the a direction is formed with an Ag···Ag distance of 6.25 Å, and at the same time, the [AgL1] chains are interlinked into highly undulate layers extending along the (010) plane (Figure ). Topologically, the layer is a highly distorted variation of the (4,4) net, with both organic (L1) and inorganic (NO3 -) linkers. The layers are stacked in parallel down the b direction (Figure ), with the nitrate ions from a layer forming C−H···O weak hydrogen bonds with the methyl groups from neighboring layers [C7−H7A···O1(1 − x, 1 − y, −z)], the H···O distance and the C−H···O angle being 2.54 Å and 174.1°, respectively.

Topologically, the layer is a highly distorted variation of the (4,4) net, with both organic (L1) and inorganic (NO3 -) linkers. The layers are stacked in parallel down the b direction (Figure ), with the nitrate ions from a layer forming C-H⋅⋅⋅O weak hydrogen bonds with the methyl groups from neighboring layers [C7-H7A⋅⋅⋅O1(1 - x, 1 - y, -z)], the H⋅⋅⋅O distance and the C-H⋅⋅⋅O angle being 2.54 Å and 174.1°, respectively.

elements.content: Discussion. The 1D [M(L)(H2O)4] coordination chain found in 1 is among the most frequently encountered coordination moiety in metal−organic supramolecular architectures with bis(pyridyl)-derived ligands. The coordinated aqua molecules in the chain are potential hydrogen donors, and so it is not surprising that the uncoordinated ligand with pyridyl groups as hydrogen-bonding acceptors is often found to cocrystallize with the coordination chain. In other words, it is likely that the cocrystallization process is induced by the formation of the coordination chain. Some high-dimensional architectures resulting from this type of coordination chains have been reported, such as 2D grid layers and 3D nets with different topologies and different M/L ratios. In the present Mn(II) complex, the hydrogen-bonded L1 molecules are aligned along the coordination chains and serve as additional “bridges” between the metal chromophores already linked by the bridging L1 ligand, leading to three-strand ribbons without dimensional increase. The ribbons are further stabilized by the π−π stacking interaction between the hydrogen-bonded L1 molecules and the bridging ones. This type of three-strand ribbon is very rare, and only a Mn(II) complex with 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), [Mn(bpe)(H2O)4](ClO4)2·4(bpe)·2H2O (3), has been shown to contain similar motifs, provided that half of the uncoordinated bpe molecules are omitted. In 3, the uncoordinated bpe molecules that are not involved in the intraribbon hydrogen bonds are hydrogen bonded to the coordinated aqua molecules from different ribbons, thus interlinking the ribbons into a complex 3D network. In the present compound, however, the ribbons are interlinked by the hydrogen-bonded perchlorate “bridges”, affording a different and triple-decked 2D layer network.
elements.clean_text: Discussion. The 1D [M(L)(H2O)4] coordination chain found in 1 is among the most frequently encountered coordination moiety in metal-organic supramolecular architectures with bis(pyridyl)-derived ligands. The coordinated aqua molecules in the chain are potential hydrogen donors, and so it is not surprising that the uncoordinated ligand with pyridyl groups as hydrogen-bonding acceptors is often found to cocrystallize with the coordination chain. In other words, it is likely that the cocrystallization process is induced by the formation of the coordination chain. Some high-dimensional architectures resulting from this type of coordination chains have been reported, such as 2D grid layers and 3D nets with different topologies and different M/L ratios. In the present Mn(II) complex, the hydrogen-bonded L1 molecules are aligned along the coordination chains and serve as additional "bridges" between the metal chromophores already linked by the bridging L1 ligand, leading to three-strand ribbons without dimensional increase. The ribbons are further stabilized by the π-π stacking interaction between the hydrogen-bonded L1 molecules and the bridging ones. This type of three-strand ribbon is very rare, and only a Mn(II) complex with 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), [Mn(bpe)(H2O)4](ClO4)2⋅4(bpe)⋅2H2O (3), has been shown to contain similar motifs, provided that half of the uncoordinated bpe molecules are omitted. In 3, the uncoordinated bpe molecules that are not involved in the intraribbon hydrogen bonds are hydrogen bonded to the coordinated aqua molecules from different ribbons, thus interlinking the ribbons into a complex 3D network. In the present compound, however, the ribbons are interlinked by the hydrogen-bonded perchlorate "bridges", affording a different and triple-decked 2D layer network.

elements.content: The rotations about the central N−N bond and about the two py−C bonds afford the L1 ligand with flexibility, thus making the ligand adaptable to different structures. In the present Mn(II) complex, the bridging ligand adopts a transoid conformation. It contrasts to the twisted spiral-like conformation found in the Co(II) and Cd(II) complexes reported previously, in which the central portion of L1 is nonplanar, and the two pyridylimine [PyC(Me)N] moieties are rotated about the central N−N bond, leading to a dihedral angle of ca. 90° between the two pyridyl rings. Also different is the relative orientation of the pyridyl and imine groups in these complexes. In 1, each pyridylimine moiety of the ligand is transoid in that the two nitrogen atoms are in the opposite sides of the Py−C bond, while for each ligand in the previous complexes, one pyridylimine moiety is transoid and the other is cisoid. These conformational differences are consistent with the different polymeric structures. The bridging coordination of the ligand in the twisted conformation to two metal ions leaves enough space for a second L1 bridge between the two metal ions, so that neighboring metal ions are linked by double L1 bridges to form M(L1)2 chains. On the other hand, the centrosymmetric transoid conformation of the bridging L1 ligand in 1 is apparently incompatible with the double bridging mode, so that single bridges between metal ions are formed. Several Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers of the L2 have also been reported, and they exhibit 2D or 3D singly bridged coordination networks with L2 adopting the transoid conformation similar to that in 1. It is still not clear why 2D or 3D coordination motifs are not formed for Mn(II) and L1, although the relatively strong affinity of Mn(II) to aqua oxygens and the steric influence of the methyl groups in packing of the molecules may play some roles.
elements.clean_text: The rotations about the central N-N bond and about the two py-C bonds afford the L1 ligand with flexibility, thus making the ligand adaptable to different structures. In the present Mn(II) complex, the bridging ligand adopts a transoid conformation. It contrasts to the twisted spiral-like conformation found in the Co(II) and Cd(II) complexes reported previously, in which the central portion of L1 is nonplanar, and the two pyridylimine [PyC(Me)N] moieties are rotated about the central N-N bond, leading to a dihedral angle of ca. 90° between the two pyridyl rings. Also different is the relative orientation of the pyridyl and imine groups in these complexes. In 1, each pyridylimine moiety of the ligand is transoid in that the two nitrogen atoms are in the opposite sides of the Py-C bond, while for each ligand in the previous complexes, one pyridylimine moiety is transoid and the other is cisoid. These conformational differences are consistent with the different polymeric structures. The bridging coordination of the ligand in the twisted conformation to two metal ions leaves enough space for a second L1 bridge between the two metal ions, so that neighboring metal ions are linked by double L1 bridges to form M(L1)2 chains. On the other hand, the centrosymmetric transoid conformation of the bridging L1 ligand in 1 is apparently incompatible with the double bridging mode, so that single bridges between metal ions are formed. Several Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers of the L2 have also been reported, and they exhibit 2D or 3D singly  bridged coordination networks with L2 adopting the transoid conformation similar to that in 1. It is still not clear why 2D or 3D coordination motifs are not formed for Mn(II) and L1, although the relatively strong affinity of Mn(II) to aqua oxygens and the steric influence of the methyl groups in packing of the molecules may play some roles.

elements.content: Because of the preference of the Ag(I) ion to (quasi-)linear coordination, single-strand chains with different geometries have been found in many Ag(I) complexes with bis(pyridyl) ligands, as reviewed by Schröder et al. It is obvious that the chain geometry depends strongly upon the substitution position of the pyridyl groups. The off-axis coordination orientation of the bis(3-pyridyl) ligands has led to nonlinear chains:  rigid ligands in the transoid conformation, such as 3,6-bis(3‘-pyridyl)tetrazine (3,3‘-bptz) and 1,4-bis(3‘-quinolyl)butadiyne (3,3‘-qubut), can form zigzag chains or deeply undulated “rectangular” chains, while the flexible 3,3-oxybispyridine ligand (3,3‘-Py2O) was reported to form helical Ag(I) chains with counteranion-tuned pitches. In the present Ag(I) complex, the centrosymmetric and planar conformation of the L1 ligand resembles the transoid conformation of the rigid 3,3‘-bptz and 3,3‘-qubut ligands, but the chain geometry is different from those reported previously. The differences arise from relative orientation of the ligands around the metal centers, as shown in Scheme . In the previously reported zigzag chains [including the Mn(II) zigzag chain in 1] or quasi-rectangular chains, the ligands adopt an anti or syn arrangement around the metal center, while the L1 ligands in 2 are arranged in a screwed fashion around the metal center, so that the chain extends in a helix-like way. We use the expression “helix-like” because the chain geometry is distinct from a genuine helix, such as that formed by 3,3‘-py2O. In the helical Ag(I) chain with 3,3‘-py2O, the screwed arrangement of the pyridyl groups around the metal center and the screwed conformation of the ligand have the same handedness, which is maintained throughout the whole chain. However, the L1 ligand in 2 adopts a centrosymmetric conformation, and so the neighboring metal centers in the chain have opposite handedness, resulting in the observed unusual chain geometry.
elements.clean_text: Because of the preference of the Ag(I) ion to (quasi-)linear coordination, single-strand chains with different geometries have been found in many Ag(I) complexes with bis(pyridyl) ligands, as reviewed by Schröder et al. It is obvious that the chain geometry depends strongly upon the substitution position of the pyridyl groups. The off-axis coordination orientation of the bis(3-pyridyl) ligands has led to nonlinear chains: rigid ligands in the transoid conformation, such as 3,6-bis(3‘-pyridyl)tetrazine (3,3‘-bptz) and 1,4-bis(3‘-quinolyl)butadiyne (3,3‘-qubut), can form zigzag chains or deeply undulated "rectangular" chains, while the flexible 3,3-oxybispyridine ligand (3,3‘-Py2O) was reported to form helical Ag(I) chains with counteranion-tuned pitches. In the present Ag(I) complex, the centrosymmetric and planar conformation of the L1 ligand resembles the transoid conformation of the rigid 3,3‘-bptz and 3,3‘-qubut ligands, but the chain geometry is different from those reported previously. The differences arise from relative orientation of the ligands around the metal centers, as shown in Scheme . In the previously reported zigzag chains [including the Mn(II) zigzag chain in 1] or quasi-rectangular chains, the ligands adopt an anti or syn arrangement around the metal center, while the L1 ligands in 2 are arranged in a screwed fashion around the metal center, so that the chain extends in a helix-like way. We use the expression "helix-like" because the chain geometry is distinct from a genuine helix, such as that formed by 3,3‘-py2O. In the helical Ag(I) chain with 3,3‘-py2O, the screwed arrangement of the pyridyl groups around the metal center and the screwed conformation of the ligand have the same handedness, which is maintained throughout the whole chain. However, the L1 ligand in 2 adopts a centrosymmetric conformation, and so the neighboring metal centers in the chain have opposite handedness, resulting in the observed unusual chain geometry.

elements.content: Arrangement of the 3-Pyridyl Groups around the Metal Center (gray balls)
elements.clean_text: 2  Arrangement of the 3-Pyridyl Groups around the Metal Center (gray balls)

elements.content: We have successfully obtained two new metal coordination polymers with unusual supramolecular architectures from the L1 ligand. In complex 1, three different types of organizing forces operate concurrently to sustain a novel triple-decked supramolecular layer structure. The coordination bonds lead to 1D zigzag [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n coordination chains which are the backbones of the structure. The hydrogen bonds between the coordinated waters and the uncoordinated ligands and the π−π stacking interactions between the coordinated and uncoordinated ligands lead to three-strand supramolecular ribbons, and the hydrogen bonds between the coordinated waters and the perchlorate ions interlink the ribbons into the interesting triple-decked supramolecular layers. In complex 2, the L1 ligands act as bridges connecting Ag(I) ions into 1D helix-like chains, which are cross-linked by μ2-nitrate ions into undulate coordination layers with interlayer C−H···O weak hydrogen bonds. These structures are different from those previously obtained from L1 and other bis(pyridyl)-derived ligands, reflecting the flexibility and coordination orientation of the L1 ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully obtained two new metal coordination polymers with unusual supramolecular architectures from the L1 ligand. In complex 1, three different types of organizing forces operate concurrently to sustain a novel triple-decked supramolecular layer structure. The coordination bonds lead to 1D zigzag [Mn(H2O)4(L1)] n  coordination chains which are the backbones of the structure. The hydrogen bonds between the coordinated waters and the uncoordinated ligands and the π-π stacking interactions between the coordinated and uncoordinated ligands lead to three-strand supramolecular ribbons, and the hydrogen bonds between the coordinated waters and the perchlorate ions interlink the ribbons into the interesting triple-decked supramolecular layers. In complex 2, the L1 ligands act as bridges connecting Ag(I) ions into 1D helix-like chains, which are cross-linked by μ2-nitrate ions into undulate coordination layers with interlayer C-H⋅⋅⋅O weak hydrogen bonds. These structures are different from those previously obtained from L1 and other bis(pyridyl)-derived ligands, reflecting the flexibility and coordination orientation of the L1 ligand.

Crystallographic data, in CIF format, are available for all the crystal structures. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

cln_elements.content:
Materials and Synthesis. All the starting chemicals were of A. R. grade and used as received. The L1 ligand was prepared according to the literature method.

CAUTION! Although not encountered in our experiments, metal perchlorates are potentially explosive. They should be handled with care.

[Mn(H 2 O) 4 (L 1 )] n (ClO 4 ) 2 n · 2 n L 1 (1). A methanol solution (4 mL) of Mn(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.20 mmol) was mixed under stirring with the solution (6 mL) of the L1 ligand (0.40 mmol) in the same solvent. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for three weeks, affording yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with methanol and ether successively, and dried in air. Yield:  74% (based on the ligand). When the starting Mn/L1 molar ratio was changed to 1:3, which corresponds to the stoichiometry of 1, the same compound was obtained. Anal. Calcd for C42H50Cl2MnN12O12:  C 48.47, H 4.84, N 16.15; Found:  C 48.40, H 4.68, N 16.55%. Main IR (cm-1):  3409m, 1614s, 1421s, 1371s, 1306m, 1200m, 1121vs, 1034s, 931m, 825m, 707m.

[Ag(L 1 )(NO 3 )] n (2). This compound was initially prepared as a polycrystalline yellow product, which precipitated immediately upon mixing the methanol solutions of L1 and AgNO3 (1:1 mole ratio), Yield:  89%. The reaction in acetonitrile gave similar results. Crystals of the compound were obtained by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube:  A dichloromethane solution (4 mL) of L1 (0.2 mmol) and an acetonitrile solution (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol) were respectively added into the two sides of the H-shaped tube, and then about 5 mL of acetonitrile was carefully added so that the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded yellow crystals of 2 within 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H14AgN5O3:  C 41.20, H 3.46, N 17.16; Found:  C 41.46, H 3.34, N 17.33%. Main IR (cm-1):  1612s, 1422m, 1353s, 1318vs, 1196m, 823m, 701m.

The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for three weeks, affording yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with methanol and ether successively, and dried in air. Yield: 74% (based on the ligand). When the starting Mn/L1 molar ratio was changed to 1:3, which corresponds to the stoichiometry of 1, the same compound was obtained. Anal. Calcd for C42H50Cl2MnN12O12: C 48.47, H 4.84, N 16.15; Found: C 48.40, H 4.68, N 16.55%. Main IR (cm-1): 3409m, 1614s, 1421s, 1371s, 1306m, 1200m, 1121vs, 1034s, 931m, 825m, 707m. 

 [Ag(L  1   )(NO  3  )]   n    (2). The reaction in acetonitrile gave similar results. Crystals of the compound were obtained by slow diffusion in a H-shaped tube: A dichloromethane solution (4 mL) of L1 (0.2 mmol) and an acetonitrile solution (3 mL) of AgNO3 (0.2 mmol) were respectively added into the two sides of the H-shaped tube, and then about 5 mL of acetonitrile was carefully added so that the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded yellow crystals of 2 within 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C14H14AgN5O3: C 41.20, H 3.46, N 17.16; Found: C 41.46, H 3.34, N 17.33%. Summary of Crystallographic Data for the Complexes
